articles.headline: A Changing Tennessee Weighs a Moderate or Conservative for Senate
articles.snippet: Phil Bredesen, the Democrat, has a centrist approach in a state that traditionally embraced moderates. His campaign is testing whether that is still viable in Tennessee.
articles.abstract: Phil Bredesen, the Democrat, has a centrist approach in a state that traditionally embraced moderates. His campaign is testing whether that is still viable in Tennessee.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — As Phil Bredesen, the former Democratic governor of Tennessee now running for Senate, was wrapping up a voter forum at Rhodes College recently, the liberal-leaning mix of students, faculty and local residents began to grow restless from his unapologetically moderate brand of politics.

articles.headline: Slumping Stock Market Enters Negative Territory for the Year
articles.snippet: Stocks dropped yet again on Wednesday, as the S.&P. 500 gave up its gains for 2018.
articles.abstract: Stocks dropped yet again on Wednesday, as the S.&P. 500 gave up its gains for 2018.
articles.lead_paragraph: Another wave of selling hit the nearly decade-long bull market as investors worried that the ideal climate they have long enjoyed — a surging economy, low interest rates and fast-growing corporate profits — would soon be behind them.

articles.headline: Tesla Reports a Rare Quarterly Profit, Its Biggest Ever
articles.snippet: A surge in sales of the Model 3 helped lift the company’s performance, but big financial and production challenges remain.
articles.abstract: A surge in sales of the Model 3 helped lift the company’s performance, but big financial and production challenges remain.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tesla on Wednesday reported its first quarterly profit in two years and its biggest ever. But for the electric-car maker and its unpredictable chief, the question is whether it can keep making money.

articles.headline: When Trump Phones Friends, the Chinese and the Russians Listen and Learn
articles.snippet: President Trump has been repeatedly told by aides that his cellphone calls are not secure from foreign spies. But he has refused to heed the warnings to stop talking.
articles.abstract: President Trump has been repeatedly told by aides that his cellphone calls are not secure from foreign spies. But he has refused to heed the warnings to stop talking.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump calls old friends on one of his iPhones to gossip, gripe or solicit their latest take on how he is doing, American intelligence reports indicate that Chinese spies are often listening — and putting to use invaluable insights into how to best work the president and affect administration policy, current and former American officials said.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: ‘Blackface’ Remarks by Megyn Kelly Lead to Rift With NBC
articles.snippet: The NBC News chairman Andrew Lack condemned her comments at a staff meeting, and three network stars publicly criticized the “Today” show host.
articles.abstract: The NBC News chairman Andrew Lack condemned her comments at a staff meeting, and three network stars publicly criticized the “Today” show host.
articles.lead_paragraph: Megyn Kelly struggled on Wednesday to contain a growing crisis over her racially insensitive remarks during a “Today” show broadcast, statements that propelled longstanding tensions between the former Fox News anchor and her NBC News colleagues into public view.
articles.byline: By John Koblin and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: How the Migrant Caravan Became a Trump Election Strategy
articles.snippet: Activists in Honduras hoped the caravan would damage a president they opposed and help migrants. Instead it precipitated a crisis that hurt them and played into President Trump’s hands.
articles.abstract: Activists in Honduras hoped the caravan would damage a president they opposed and help migrants. Instead it precipitated a crisis that hurt them and played into President Trump’s hands.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras — The flier began circulating on social media in Honduras this month, showing a lone migrant sketched against a bright red backdrop.
articles.byline: By Azam Ahmed, Katie Rogers and Jeff Ernst

articles.headline: A ‘People’s Pig’ in China Could Be Headed to Upstate New York
articles.snippet: Their farm threatened by a modernization drive, four specimens of a rare breed of swine need a new home. A Rockefeller scion may save them.
articles.abstract: Their farm threatened by a modernization drive, four specimens of a rare breed of swine need a new home. A Rockefeller scion may save them.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Abby Rockefeller wants to bring the People’s Pig of the Northeast back to the people. First, she has to bring it to upstate New York.

articles.headline: Apple News’s Radical Approach: Humans Over Machines
articles.snippet: While Google, Facebook and Twitter face scrutiny for spreading misinformation, Apple has avoided scandal by using people to pick what news to show. Is that good for news outlets?
articles.abstract: While Google, Facebook and Twitter face scrutiny for spreading misinformation, Apple has avoided scandal by using people to pick what news to show. Is that good for news outlets?
articles.lead_paragraph: Many of Apple’s employees moved into a glistening new $5 billion glass headquarters in Cupertino, Calif., this year. A mile west, at Apple’s old campus on 1 Infinite Loop, a project antithetical to Silicon Valley’s ethos is now underway.

articles.headline: A Black Senate Candidate Stumps in Mississippi, but His Party Holds Him Back
articles.snippet: Mike Espy, former President Clinton’s agriculture secretary, could emerge as the top vote-getter in Mississippi’s Senate race on Election Day, but the runoff will be the hard part.
articles.abstract: Mike Espy, former President Clinton’s agriculture secretary, could emerge as the top vote-getter in Mississippi’s Senate race on Election Day, but the runoff will be the hard part.
articles.lead_paragraph: INDIANOLA, Miss. — When Mike Espy, a young black lawyer from a prominent local family, first campaigned for Congress in this tidy Delta town 30 years ago, many white voters refused to shake his hand. The onetime home of both B. B. King and the White Citizens’ Council, Indianola embodied the gulf that has divided Mississippi for centuries.

articles.headline: Saudi Arabia, in Reversal, Suggests Khashoggi’s Killing Was Premeditated
articles.snippet: The announcement that the dissident writer’s death may have been planned was the latest shift in the kingdom’s official account of what happened.
articles.abstract: The announcement that the dissident writer’s death may have been planned was the latest shift in the kingdom’s official account of what happened.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Saudi Arabia’s public prosecutor acknowledged for the first time on Thursday that the killing of the dissident columnist Jamal Khashoggi appeared to have been premeditated — yet another shift in the kingdom’s account of his disappearance in Turkey.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Megyn Kelly’s ‘Blackface’ Remarks Leave Her Future at NBC in Doubt
articles.snippet: The host’s standing at the network appeared shaky even before she made incendiary remarks on Tuesday. Her recent apologies have not won her much support.
articles.abstract: The host’s standing at the network appeared shaky even before she made incendiary remarks on Tuesday. Her recent apologies have not won her much support.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the Tuesday episode of her show, Megyn Kelly made remarks on blackface Halloween costumes that caused a backlash. On Wednesday, she looked into the camera and apologized. On Thursday, she did not go to work, and a rerun of “Megyn Kelly Today” replaced the live broadcast of her show.
articles.byline: By John Koblin and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: Trump, Partisan and Pugilist, Abandons Calls for Unity After Bomb Scares
articles.snippet: The president again chooses confrontation over conciliation. His caustic approach to politics echoes through the rest of the political food chain.
articles.abstract: The president again chooses confrontation over conciliation. His caustic approach to politics echoes through the rest of the political food chain.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In moments of national crisis, presidents typically reach for unifying themes, as Bill Clinton did after the Oklahoma City bombing and George W. Bush did with the bullhorn on the wrecked fire truck after 9/11. President Trump on Thursday chose confrontation over conciliation.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Jeremy W. Peters
